Let me tell you, Slay the Spire is one of those games that feels like a chaotic, card-flinging whirlwind at first. You’ll dive in, gleefully throwing random attacks, eating curses for breakfast, and wondering why the elite just turned you into a squishy pancake in two turns. But here’s the thing: the more you play, the more you realize – this game is way less about luck and way more about skill.

At its heart, Slay the Spire is a masterclass in combos and synergies. Sure, you might pick up a seemingly random hand of cards at first, but once you start connecting the dots, it’s like solving a puzzle where each piece gives you a new power boost. Get the right relics, nail the perfect card synergy, and suddenly, you’re a juggernaut of destruction, making bosses look like confused kittens.

And let's not forget the randomness – it’s what keeps things interesting! Each run is different, and while luck can sometimes throw you a curveball, true Spire-slayers know how to adapt, turning even the most cursed hands into epic victories. The randomness isn't frustrating – it's exciting! Every run is like shaking a magic 8-ball that could either tell you you're about to destroy everything... or that you're about to get destroyed.

The beauty of this game is how it tricks you. It starts out feeling chaotic, but the more you play, the more you realize it’s a perfectly balanced dance of risk and reward. And the deeper you go, the more the "luck" turns into skill, knowledge, and—let’s be real—just pure card-flipping satisfaction.

So, if you're ready to flex your brain while occasionally cursing the RNG gods, and absolutely dominating the spire with your killer combos, this is the game for you. Happy slaying!

My actual playtime is around 35 hours when including mobile. I can't recommend this game enough, perfect for one and done players like me (beat the game once on all four characters), and even better for players who want to sink hundreds of hours into a high skill ceiling game. I enjoy the puzzle of working out how to beat the current enemy with your current deck plus the puzzle of what cards to take in order to strengthen your deck so you can beat future enemies. The interactions between cards and the hope (and randomness) of getting offered the right card makes each playthrough feel different. Plus the game is very well balanced so defeat or victory always feel like options. Additionally the variety of interactions makes each playthrough slightly unique, there are still combinations I have not seen or played despite playing for almost 2k hours.
In short, it's the best in class. If you enjoy this kind of game, don't hesitate. If you aren't sure, don't hesitate either. It's a cheap game :)

If you like roguelikes and deck-building, this is the game for you.
An amazing fusion of tabletop gaming and video gaming that consistently provides challenge, room for creativity, and repeatability. 

Pros:
1. Great variety in builds. I enjoy deck-builders because you can't guarantee what build you'll have every time so it's fun to be forced to think about what cards you want to make your build work!
2. Mods! If you get bored, there's a decent modding community that brings a whole new light to the game
3. Challenge. I'm obsessed with getting all the achievements because they present an exciting difficulty that I can brag to my friends about. 

Cons:
1. Sound and music is repetitive. Not really that big of a deal, but I hope they put more effort into the sound design of the sequel.
2. Art style. I think the art style isn't everyone's favorite. Really minor stuff.

Obviously I'm reaching on the cons here. If you like this type of game, I'm not sure why you wouldn't enjoy it. Otherwise, if you don't enjoy it, It's probably not because of the game itself, but your personal preference.

Slay the Spire is a fast, high risk high reward, chaotic, most of the time unbalanced, and super fun game. it's core design is simple and effective. combos and cards are exciting, you start every run saying "i wonder what kind of crazy build i'll have this time!". the problem starts when you realize that actually this game is highly randomized. now, of course it's randomized, it's a rougelike. 

but without specific combos or builds it's almost impossible to win that run. this type of design creates this problem: at the start of the run you may get like 2 cards that create synergy or can be used in an advanced build, but doing this will probably cause you to die at the start of the game since you chose the not that storng cards but valuable to builds cards. the other side is you can choose the good cards or the cards that create synergy with each other but are not part of a grand build. this causes you to fail late stages of the game. both of these routes causes you to fail. so how do you win the game? it's 80% luck, and i'm saying this as someone who reached ascension 11. 

despite all this this is a great game. core mechanic design makes the decision process very fast, it doesn't get stale with time. synergies do a great job making you feel smart and powerful. it's a great game.

A highly addictive rogue-lite deckbuilder. Fight in matches, kind of like MTG-lite. Each time you win, you choose a card to get and add to your deck. The goal is to build the best deck synergy to get to the end (because the enemies get harder). There are four characters/deck types to play, and it's random what cards you get, so you may end up with a run you know is not going to win and have to quit. But it's strangely fun despite that frustration. The game pulls no punches with difficulty--you can't win every go-round. But you still want to try again like a gambler.
It's my go-to game when I don't have much time or I'm killing some time and need something quick but engaging. I love it!

It's the first game to do the rogue-like deck-builder and after 7 years it still remains the best rogue-like deck-builder out there.

The game is very deep and the possible card/relic synergies are endless. After hundreds of runs I have had countless runs where the power and play-style of the deck was entirely unique compared to the rest.

The best feeling is when you're barely keeping up with the difficulty curve in a run, and suddenly the deck magically comes together, card synergies just emerge out of nowhere, and you identify your win condition.  

The game rewards creativity and pivoting - you cannot force a certain archetype. But every run is winnable if you are intelligent about how you build given the resources offered.

I highly recommend to anyone who's played a rogue-like and enjoyed it. And the mobile version of the game is fantastic, despite what you may have read elsewhere. It's exactly the same just with different UI. So investing time in this game comes with the plus of being able to enjoy it on mobile as well. (And StS2 is coming soon!).

[h3] Difficulty [/h3]
There are 20 difficulties to progress through once you win a run. So if you want to climb up the difficulties the game continuously gets very hard. There is a high skill ceiling but the added difficulty at the higher levels do not feel unfair or overly punishing. Completing the highest difficulty will take time, which is a good thing IMO. I'm at 15+ out of 20 on all 4 characters.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
The game is exceptionally smooth to play, and all of the UI actions feel great. There is good QoL like "fast" mode where all animations and delays are reduced in time (it does not feel unnatural, it's done intelligently).

Each character is very different from each other and each has tons of possible deck archetypes available which play differently. There is a great amount of cards and relics, and the vast majority of deck themes have enough support available to be viable and flexible.

If you like feeling overpowered with a stupidly powerful or cheesy deck (like infinites and OTKs), those decks are possible and entirely viable but still not imbalanced (you can't force synergies, only identify them when available).

The graphics are divisive, and for me they are nothing special, kinda wonky. I enjoy the silly lore and world-building. 

Lastly, if you're like me and don't care for playing-card games due to their prohibitive expenses, grinding, and PvP frustration, this serves as a much better card game fix that is reasonably priced, PvE, and feels fair.

After playing it on my Nintendo Switch, Slay the Spire quickly became one of my favorite games. It wasn’t long before I picked it up on Steam as well, mainly because I wanted to go after all the achievements—and let’s be honest, some of them will be pretty challenging. But that’s part of the fun, right?

I’ve already won with Ironclad and The Defect, and now I’m working on The Silent (even though I managed to beat the game with them first on my Switch). Out of all the characters, The Silent has to be my favorite. There’s something so satisfying about stacking poison and shiv attacks. The ticking poison damage combined with the no-cost shivs creates this amazing feeling of control in battle—especially when you get the right deck build going. And that’s the double-edged sword of Slay the Spire: waiting for that perfect card to complete your deck can be both exhilarating and frustrating. Sometimes, it just never comes, but hey, that’s all part of the fun.

I tend to avoid elites or mini-bosses because, well, they’ve killed me more times than I can count. Sure, I’m not the best at this game, but that doesn’t stop me from trying to get better and score a win. Even with all the losses, each run feels like a fresh challenge, and that’s what keeps me coming back. Plus, I’m really looking forward to the second Slay the Spire game. Hopefully, I can finish all the achievements in the first game before it comes out.

I’ve also been experimenting with The Watcher, the fourth character, though I haven’t quite cracked their deck yet. The Watcher’s playstyle is way different from the others, requiring me to switch up my approach entirely. I’ll need to treat this character very differently from the rest, but I’m excited to explore how their stance mechanics work once I get a better handle on them.

Oh, and something else I’m curious about is the lore. Slay the Spire seems to have these snippets of story or background scattered throughout, and I need to dive deeper into that sometime.

In the end, Slay the Spire is an addictive, challenging, and strategic experience that deck-building fans shouldn’t miss. Even when the game is against you, there’s always that sense of ‘just one more run’—and it’s so worth it.

I'm going to write this as a review, but also as a very broad new player guide, as I believe that understanding what it takes to be good at the game will help you understand why the game is good. Don't worry, i'm not going to ruin the fun of figuring the game out for yourself, I'm just going to go over the general thought processes this game encourages to show you why the game is so beloved.

STS is a roguelike deckbuilder. Roguelikes are random, and card games are random, so the game must be random^2, right? As random as these two genres are, the randomness of each of these components is heavily limited in many ways. The map generation follows certain rules and regulations, the enemy variety at each stage of the game is limited, and the card pool for each character is modest. Despite the seeming lack of variety, the game is full of interesting decisions because so much of the game is foreseeable. As you get familiar with the game, you'll find yourself being able to evaluate the strength of different cards with increasing accuracy as your understanding of the challenges in front of you deepens. If the game had 9 billion different enemies and cards, your choices would feel so much more meaningless and shallow. However, since the game was designed with restraint and predictability, as soon as you're offered your first choice of cards on the first floor, you'll often find yourself deciding between a card that is immediately strong, or a card that might be clunky now but could really pay off later. The card's you are offered are random, but you're always evaluating them against a predictable set of challenges.

A common piece of advice I see for new players is that they shouldn't think about building a certain archetype of deck, they should be thinking about picking cards that give them the tools they need to deal with the challenges in front of them. I'm bringing this up because its very easy to go into this game with the wrong mindset, which will ultimately be detrimental and frustrating for you. In order to be successful in slay the spire, you will have to stretch the definition of synergy with your card selections and come up with a swiss army knife of a deck that can meet the demands of any situation. You can't just pick all of the shiv spam cards that obviously work well together. If you do that, then the enemy that punishes you for spamming shivs will kill your run. Of course, a lot of people would like it if you could just pick the obvious synergy package and win every run, but those people would get bored of the game after a few runs because the card evaluation process would be as braindead as looking for cards that have keywords your deck already has. STS often encourages you to pick a card that might not fit perfectly with the rest of your deck because you need a solution for a tough enemy coming up. For example, one time I had a defect deck that was based entirely around his orb mechanic, but I knew that I had no way to scale them up to finish off a boss with a massive health pool, so I took a single copy of claw, a completely non-orb related card that gets stronger every time you play it during a fight, and relied solely on that to get my way through the boss. This wasn't a rare card, its a common and not even a particularly good one, but It did something the rest my deck didn't. Another great example of this sort of thing happening is when a top player named baalorlord picked clash, and everyone was like "wtf, why would you do that? Clash sucks ass!" baalorlord went on to win the run and set a world record for most wins in a row. If he did not pick that shitty card, there's a very good chance he would have died. For the record, clash is pretty garbage.

Now that I've explained why i like the game so much, I need to be fair and say its not completely perfect. Getting through the first few floors can be kinda boring sometimes, there are a few regular enemies that are a little too punishing (fuck gremlin gang, snake plant, and the avocado guy), act 2 in general has a bit of a difficulty spike that could be tuned down whereas act 3 can often feel too easy as a final act, and a lot of the events that give you a curse in return for something good are rarely ever worth it because curses are just so horrible. That being said, those issues are fairly minor and the game is still one of my favorites of all time.

I hope this review was helpful and gave you some insight into why this game is loved by so many people.

It took me a really long time to decide to buy this game. 

I would often read the overwhelmingly positive reviews, but I really did not dig the artstyle at all. Furthermore, for some reason I was not really into the idea of a roguelike deckbuilder, I don't know why...
Anyway, one day the game was on discount and I had some extra credit on my steam account, so I decided to buy it.

Boy, was I wrong! This is one of the most addictive games I have ever played. It took me ~7 years to play this masterpiece! I just beat act iv on all characters and I am now starting the Ascension mode of the game. 
I cannot recommend this game enough! The gameplay is exactly what I love in a game: easy to learn but hard to master. Additionally, the gameplay loop is addictive making you to want to finish your run, no matter if you win or loose. 

Like in every roguelike, RNG is a major part of the game. Nevertheless, the mobs and bosses are almost never impossible to beat, they are completely fair. One only looses if they make questionable decisions in their card rotations, relics, paths etc... This does not mean that the player has to follow a specific/narrow path to victory. There are a plethora of ways/builds in which you can beat the game.  

I recommend this game to everyone, no matter if you like deckbuilders or not. This game is a steal even at full price!

Extra reasons why I love this game:
1) Lot's of community mods for infinite replayability.
2) Works flawlessly on Linux/Steam Deck
3) Slay the Spire 2 will use the free and open-source game engine, Godot. 
4) I now actually love the artstyle

Slay the Spire is a pioneer of deckbuilder roguelikes. Maybe not the first to do it, but possibly the most critically acclaimed and well-known. It's created many genre mainstays like the Enemy/Elite/Shop/Chest/Boss map design. And it holds up extremely well compared to similarly aged peers like The Binding of Isaac: Afterbirth and Enter the Gungeon. I just didn't like it. It is incredibly fun to [strike]backseat[/strike] watch, and I believe it's overall pretty well made, but there's many strange kinks its spiritual successors have hammered out, and I just didn't overall vibe with the playstyle it demands.
[h2] Pros [/h2]
[list]
    [*][url=https://forgottenarbiter.github.io/Is-Every-Seed-Winnable/]There is a mathematically unwinnable win.[/url] And yet, no one's actually found it. There's been pretty close to unwinnable seeds, but even those have been beaten. By all means (unless you've made a one of a kind discovery), a loss is purely a skill issue.
    [*]Synergy building is fun. It's always a good time doing 200 damage with a Heavy Blade, racking up 10x more Poison than the enemy has health, or beating combat by just mashing End Turn as Defect.
    [*]The art design is wonderful. I thoroughly enjoy the painted visual style and orchestral music.
    [*]Custom Mode gives you a TON of customization options for how a run can play out, particularly if you just want a pure power fantasy. Though, it's segregated from the main intended progression of hiking up the mountain of difficulty. 
[/list]
[h2] Toss-Ups [/h2]
[list]
    [*][b]Every[/b] action you take matters. It's pretty easy to trace a failed run to one bad turn, one card choice early in the run, or one purchase you didn't make. Many Relics amp this up to a degree I find tedious. Items like Pen Nib doubling the damage of every 10th Attack, or Incense Burner making you invincible every 6 turns. These effects carry between encounters. Many of my runs have been lost to Incense Burner being the "wrong number". 
    [*]Slay the Spire heavily rewards slow play. The more you think on every action you take, the better odds you have of being successful, particularly due to the previous bullet point. Roguelikes typically have a given run time of around 60 minutes. Spire runs can easily drag on to 2 hours 30 minutes. Playing quickly AND well is a very difficult skill to learn.
    [*]There's a default run difficulty, and then 20 Ascension levels after you must clear to "beat" the game. There are four playable characters, and Ascensions are tracked individually. Clearing everything on the 300 hour mark is feasible, but it may appear tedious to some, particularly if you much prefer one character's playstyle to another.
[*]Slay the Spire is very difficult. And many community truisms and "guides" are outright detrimental to learning. Most of my playtime was hampered by bad "advice" that was very difficult to unlearn.
 [*]The playstyles of a high power and low power run are miles apart. I bought this game after watching cool busted crazy flashy runs. What I was met with was a lot of getting garbage cards my first three fights, walking up to the first Elite, and then dying due to lack of damage. On the one hand, you can get a bunch of busted cards and items early, and brainlessly romp through the Spire in about 40 minutes (also known as playing Watcher). On the other hand, you can struggle every turn you play, get mostly mediocre power boosts, take the harshest Boss Relics because you have no choice, and barely scrape by after almost 3 hours (also known as playing Silent). And the higher the Ascension level, the more likely it is to be the latter. Definitely caught me by surprise. [/list]
[h2] Cons [/h2]
[list]
    [*]Watcher shouldn't exist. Everything else in the game is centered around the three of Ironclad, Silent, and Defect. The Fighter, Thief, and Magician. The three of them represent Attacks, Skills, and Powers, and Red, Green, and Blue respectively.  You can see this trinity of design in the cards they get, relics they get, and even items such as the three Keys. Watcher not only breaks this trinity, she breaks the game. Her typical "Stance Dance" rotation generates the highest damage and highest energy efficiency of every character while also generating large amounts of block at the same time. 90% of her fights end in one or two turns. Cards such as Tantrum, Talk to the Hand, and Mental Fortress make the supposed glass cannon zero risk, all reward. She sticks out like an overpowered modded OC.
    [*] The starting decks are terrible and uninteresting. Every character starts with 4 basic Strikes and 4 Defends. The Ironclad gets an extra Strike. The Silent gets an extra Strike and Defend. This puts them at a disadvantage, since the objective of every run is to remove as many Strikes and Defends as possible because they're just not worth the energy cost. There's a Boss Relic called Pandora's Box that replaces all Strikes and Defends with random cards. It is purely beneficial in almost every scenario. There's an event that upgrades all your Strikes and Defends for free, and you still want to remove them first thing. Curse cards are skipped not because of their downside, but because it means you have to remove a Curse next and not a Strike or Defend. One of the most powerful items is the Peace Pipe, which lets you remove a card (Strike or Defend) at each campsite. Other deckbuilders solve this by making their basic cards upgrade into far more useful, synergistic things, or simply not having crappy starter decks.
[*] Boss Relic design sucks. You gain 3 energy a turn, and spend energy to play cards. Most cards cost 1, but they can cost 0-5, or all your held energy (X). Not having 4 energy, or at least a lot of other "Gain energy when X" Relics + a lot of low cost, high output cards, puts you at a MASSIVE disadvantage. Thus, when you defeat the bosses of Act 1 and Act 2, you're offered to take 1 of 3 selected Boss Relics. They're typically "Gain 1 more Energy per turn, but X". Such as Runic Dome's downside of "You can no longer see enemy Intents." Note that there is an enemy who's intent randomly changes each time it is damaged. Or Busted Crown's "On Card Reward screens, you have 2 fewer cards to choose from (the baseline is 3)." You can guess how fun those are. Once, as my first boss reward, I was offered the choice between Runic Dome, Busted Crown, and Ectoplasm (Gain 1 Energy at the start of each turn. You can no longer gain Gold.) I just quit the run right there. The purely beneficial ones (Tiny House, most character specific Boss Relics that aren't Watcher's) are usually just terrible or also exceedingly niche. Or you can just play Watcher, and easily go infinite with just 3 energy.
[*]The design of a lot of enemies is exceedingly annoying. I find that many are designed particularly around punishing The Silent's playstyle. The Malleable ability makes enemies gain block each time they take damage. The Silent particularly trends towards doing lots of small hits, so this penalizes her much more than The Ironclad's few big hits, The Defect's purely passive damage, and The Watcher's lots of big hits. Thorns is the same thing, but you take damage when you damage the enemy. One of the most infamous Elites is Gremlin Nob, an enemy who deals more damage every time you play a Skill Card. Guess which character is the most Skill focused. In general, every single enemy will either flee, or infinitely scale up in damage dealt to encourage killing enemies quickly, and discourage mostly blocking and slowly chipping away at the enemy, or at least stalling that simply blocks too little. You would not believe what The Silent's playstyle is based around.
[/list]

I nonetheless recommend Slay the Spire to anyone who [i]does[/i] want a slow, highly thought focused strategic experience (Watcher is excluded from this). I just lack the patience for it.

[h1]A true pioneer of its genre, and to this day, no one has managed to dethrone it. Welcome to the world of deck-building roguelikes.[/h1]

It’s not because the game keeps updating or changing; in fact, it’s stayed mostly the same over time. You can come back after months or even years and get that same core experience. But maybe this time, you’ll try a new strategy. With multiple characters, each having unique abilities and deck archetypes, there’s always something fresh to explore. While every card is playable, there are definitely good and bad ones, and depending on which bosses you face, one archetype might outperform another—but you only get limited information on your enemies.

The challenge comes from limited resources: is a card good for your deck? Should you upgrade, remove, or duplicate cards? Do you take a powerful artifact at the cost of your health, or skip it? There’s no right or wrong answer—you make the call, and as the run goes on, your decisions become more crucial.

The game is balanced, thoughtful, and endlessly intriguing, but what really keeps you hooked is the desire to improve. It may take some time to complete your first run and find a build that works for you. But then? You’ll want more. You’ll crave higher difficulties, more refined decks, bigger risks for bigger rewards. You might even start overkilling bosses and speedrunning. There’s always entertainment and challenge waiting, every time you replay it.

This game is the villain origin story of my roguelike obsession, and it remains my all-time favorite in my Steam library.

Starting out can be tough, especially for those new to the genre. Winning will take time and effort, but once the game’s addictive pull sets in, you’ll have an incredible time.

I recommend it to anyone, whether you're a newcomer looking for a challenging introduction to roguelikes and deck-building, or a veteran who hasn’t yet embraced this masterpiece—it’s worth every minute of your time.

New York styled Pizza:
Pizza dough:
14 g instant yeast
617g water - 95F
950g all-purpose flour
19g fine sea salt
25g granulated sugar
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
1 tablespoon (14g) butter
1 tablespoon (9g) extra virgin olive oil
6 cloves garlic, rough chopped
2 teaspoons (4g) red pepper flakes
28 oz (794g) can of crushed tomato
2 teaspoons (2g) dried oregano
1.5 tablespoons (21g) granulated sugar
salt and pepper to taste
Splash of olive oil
2 cups (227g) low moisture mozzarella, fresh grated
2 cups (200g) Monterey jack cheese, fresh grated
1/2 cup (26g) parmigiano reggiano, fresh grated
American Pizza Dough:
Preheat the oven and a baking steel or pizza stone at 500F for 45 minutes before utilizing it.
Whisk yeast and sugar into your water, and allow it to sit for 5 minutes. In a separate bowl, add flour and salt and mix by hand to combine. Pour your water mixture into your flour and mix by hand until you get a rough dough, then transfer to a work surface and knead until it starts to pull away from the work surface and is relatively smooth.
Place your dough in a greased bowl, then cover with plastic wrap and let rise for 1 - 2 hours at room temperature or until double in size.
Punch down your dough and dive into 300g pieces. Form those pieces into balls and place them in a floured proofing pizza box, cover with a lid, and proof at room temperature for 3 - 4 hours. (If you do not have a proofing pizza box, you can use a floured baking sheet, cover it with an inverted baking sheet and wrap it in plastic wrap.)
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
In a medium sauce pot, add butter and olive oil. Set that over medium-high heat; once the butter melts add garlic, cook until fragrant, add pepper flakes, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the garlic begins to brown on the edges.
Add crushed tomatoes, oregano, salt, and a splotch of olive oil, boil over medium-high, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 12 minutes, stirring occasionally or until thickened and viscous—season with salt to taste and let it cool down.
Assembly.- Place one of your pizza doughs onto a floured pizza peel, and flour your dough generously.
Punch your dough down in the center, working your way out to create a ¼” wide. Pick up your dough, place it over your closed fists, and rotate it around, gently stretching to 13” to 14”.
Place a couple of spoons of your sauce, starting in the center, spreading in little circles, and working your way to the edge until it gets evenly spread out.
In a medium-size mixing bowl, place mozzarella cheese, Monterey Jack, and Parmigiano; mix until combined. Sprinkle your cheese mixture to your desire and place in the oven onto your baking steel and bake for 5 - 7 minutes or until the edge gets golden brown and the cheese melts.
Enjoy.

There's a reason why Slay the Spire has become the gold standard for roguelike deckbuilders. Absolute masterclass of card game design. Slay the Spire is mechanically pretty simple if you're used to deckbuilding. It does not have many unique characters, bosses, or areas. However, the game makes up for it in it's depth. A level of depth I've seen few roguelikes in general match up to.

Every deck type, every enemy encounter, every card new addition; they all present interesting decision points for the player that keep the game interesting long after you've seen it all. I can't begin to imagine how difficult it was to make so many different moving parts of the course of a run fit in together, but they managed it somehow. I have over 200 hours between multiple devices in Slay the Spire and yet I'm only knee deep with how far this game can go. If you've not played a roguelike deckbuilder before, I can't think of a better place to start.

This game can be best described as the perfect mix Magic The Gathering and Risk of Rain that you didn't even know you needed. If you like to build decks that can go on forever in magic and get you a bunch of "blockers" or free "attackers" then this game has it. If you like the item system in Risk of Rain and everything has either a positive buff or negative debuff (or MOST times even both), this game has definitely has that too. Are you just looking for something to consume HUNDREDS of hours of your life just because you're bored? Well guess what, that is EASILY possible in this game as well. Even though this game isn't even a full gigabyte, there is plenty of things to do in this game to keep you entertained. Every run generates a random seed with multiple random chances for encounters, events, card rewards, potion rewards, and shop encounters, while still having a set path with guaranteed fights and loot as well as chances to regain health or upgrade a card in your deck. With each seed being different, you will never have the same run through on any run in this game, especially with there being multiple ways to build your decks. Maybe you want to specialize in gaining block and doing damage equal to the amount of block you have. Maybe you like to deal damage by exhausting (exiling for you folks who play MTG) cards. Maybe you want to deal poison damage or even build a deck to ALWAYS have lethal on an enemy. There are a seemingly endless amount of possibilities in this game to make each and every run unique and interesting (especially since there is an item you can receive that will allow you to gain cards from other characters, which there are 4 of). Once you beat the act 3 boss on any character, you will unlock an ascension level for that character. Ascension is basically new game + but there are 20 levels total each doing different things (that also stack onto each other the further you go) to further make the game difficult if you are looking for challenge. All in all, there's just so much to do in this game and i have well over the 134 hours on steam (at the time of this review) in this game because i also have it on my phone, and i still haven't gotten past ascension 6 on either device. This game, for as small as it is, just has so much to do in it and a never ending cycle of fun no matter how much time you put into it. So if you are thinking of buying the game, don't even wait for it to go on sale if you can afford it, because it is worth every penny spent. It is a 10/10 game and i have zero regrets putting in so much time into it.

[h1] Just when I thought I was out.. [/h1]
...they pull me back in! 

Wow, Slay the Spire (StS) is an amazing deck-builder in itself but the mod-community for this game is something else. There are hundreds of hours worth of expansions (Downfall Expansion is SO GOOD) which makes the game replayability go from ‘yeah no worries, I can play this game for years’ to ‘they will find me playing Slay the Spire until the casket closes’. 

[h3] The way it just.. clicks[/h3]

You know what I love about a good deckbuilder? That after some playing sessions you get the feeling your skills rise but the difficulty rises with it. StS does this as well, giving you a look into the games different ‘heroes’ and unlocking some additional cards and relics before ramping up the difficulty. It makes the game easy to learn, hard to master. 

After some sessions you know which cards to look out for and sometimes when to not pick up any cards when presented with a battle reward screen. Less is more, because more cards mean a tougher time to really get your deck to ‘click’. And boy, when it clicks, it feels amazing. I like ‘The Silent’ a lot, a poison based more defensive hero. When you get the amount of poison added per turn and defence just right, you can tackle any enemy, no matter how tough. Thing is, to get it to that point takes time, skill, knowing what cards to choose and which to ignore altogether. 

[h3] Art style, sound, visuals [/h3]
StS shines in its UI simplicity, cards are presented in the bottom centre of your screen (like most deckbuilders have I suppose). Each card has it’s own name, icon and description. What makes StS so accessible is that you don’t have to learn each of the modifiers by heart. When hovering over a card, a status, a hero/enemy you are presented this nice overview about what every stat means (and there are a TON). 

The art style feels almost like a painting, it’s basic but beautiful. Animations are great without overdoing it. When I used to play Magic: The Gathering this was the style I’d always imagine it looking when playing a deckbuilder. Background are amazing as well which each of them fitting to the situation you’re in (fight, merchant, et cetera). 

The overall sound is great, although I would have liked a more diverse soundtrack. Its not that the music gets repetitive easily but when fights go on for a longer time I sometimes notice it. Take this with a grain of salt though, I have played this game many hundreds of hours on PS already before buying it on Steam. 

[h3] But the downside, tell me about them![/h3]

Yeah okay, this is the part where I start writing about some of the stuff I’m missing. Here it comes.

Nothing.

There is this occasional feeling that a run feels doomed from the start, but what do you expect? There is some RNG involved in deckbuilders, there’s nothing you can do about it. Good thing is, you start noticing it earlier and earlier as you play more games. The trade-off for not getting some of the cards to make your deck ‘click’ is by going for another run and having the most amazing deck ever. 

There are so many times that I just say out loud: “Amazing”. Because StS makes you feel like it gives you all these tiny pieces to complete the most (in later stages) difficult puzzle ever made. But then you lay down the outer edges, you grab another card/relic, it fits, all of a sudden you went from surviving to destroying everything. The credits roll and you feel this huge feeling of having accomplished something special. 

Amazing.

This game is marketed as "combining deckbuilders and roguelikes", so, as a huge fan of both deckbuilders and roguelikes, I was very interested in trying this game.

However, this is actually just a deckbuilder with no roguelike elements! It appears that this game is called roguelike because of adapting the event system from FTL, however that event system was a Rogue-unlike innovation of that game -- roguelikes usually have spatial consistency which is much more interesting strategically.

It is great that Slay the Spire has inspired hundreds of game developers to create more solitaire deckbuilders, and other "Spire-likes". These games tend to have "roguelike deckbuilder" tag, despite being even less roguelike, and sometimes not deckbuilders. This misleading marketing made the landscape worse (by hiding actual roguelikes which are great games) and thus is a reason to leave a negative review.

I have played quite a lot of Slay the Spire, and it was fun, but then, moved back to Dominion (the game which started the deckbuilder genre) and Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup (the best roguelike). I would recommend all Slay the Spire fans to play these games. (Dominion is best to play at dominion.games for free, and DCSS is a free game!) 

Also play Dream Quest, the game which actually coined the "roguelike deckbuilder" term -- and is somehow much less popular. I would not call it a roguelike (it is more like Desktop Dungeons: there is no spatial consistency, the map is a bit like in a roguelike but the monsters do not move on it), but it is an honest combination.

I played a little of Slay the Spire a little while ago, enough to beat it with the main characters, and then I dropped it. Recently I've picked it back up to grind out ascension levels and I realized this game is digital crack. It's insane how different each run can play out, even as the same character. There is so much variety in how you get to build out your deck, and each run has a very satisfying sense of progression to it. StS perfectly straddles the line between giving the player enough choice to make meaningful decisions without giving them too much freedom to become completely overpowered. 

The ascension system is a genius difficulty setting. Each ascension level introduces a new difficulty modifier at a gradual enough pace to feel challenging without being overwhelming. These modifiers may be small and iterative but they have a tremendous impact on how you go about playing the game and making decisions, especially as they begin to stack on top of each other. 

While each run can feel unique, many of the enemy encounters are very predictable. This is actually a huge positive for StS, as it lets you plan out your deck to combat potential encounters for each floor. You never know exactly what enemies you will run into, but as you play the game more and more, you will have a better idea of what to expect. Even if I lose a run to an enemy I felt unprepared to fight, it rarely feels like the game's fault because of this.

While the graphics and animations are plain, and the music can get repetitive, that hardly matters. The act of playing StS itself is very satisyfing, especially on the fast mode. This game almost has a hypnotic effect, kind of like the Tetris effect for me. It's the only game I've ever played where I will get lost in it and then realize I've been playing until 3am.

I've been thoroughly enjoying "Slay the Spire." Although I'm relatively new to this genre, the game's mechanics are smooth, and the challenge it presents is genuinely engaging. The learning curve is quick and enjoyable, with an art style that beautifully complements the game's atmosphere. If you're in search of a game that's both relaxing and immersive, "Slay the Spire" is an excellent choice.

I love playing TCGs and this game was right up my alley. I was recommended this game for years and like all people that play other card games you say "Yeah sure I'll give it a try." but didn't for years. When the game went on sale I decided sure why not.  Holy crap. After over 360 hours a few months later with all characters at ascension 20 I can say I am kicking myself for not playing this amazing deck builder sooner. The game feels challenging right at the start because you are learning the cards and what feels good in a deck and what doesn't. But the game opens up the more you learn and the more you start to see the synergies between cards. It becomes addicting getting the farther and farther you go, the more wins you have and the higher your ascension. The game is almost perfectly balanced. The only thing I wanted more of is story even though without it, it is almost a perfect single player card game. All that being said that is not even mentioning the huge plethora of mods that can completely change the game play experience. I know I sounds like every other one of your other card player friends trying to get you into another game but, play the game. It's amazing.

Slay the Spire is a highly addictive roguelike card battler game. It's a dream come true for card battler enthusiasts.

Here are the pros:
- There are four characters in the game, each with their own unique style and abilities.
- The characters can be played in various styles. Your warrior can choose to be a heavy-hitter, a shield-bearing tank, a swift and agile attacker, or a bottomless energy pit using his own health to get a constant power boost and dominate the board. You can also mix and match different playstyles using artifacts.
- The game features a total of 730 cards and numerous relics.
- Slay the Spire has a friendly learning curve, but it also offers challenges for players of all skill levels. After completing the game, you can enter ascension mode and face increasingly difficult levels.
- The game offers different modes such as daily climbs and endless modes, adding more variety and fun.
- Steam mod support is available, and there is a substantial expansion-sized mod for the game.
- The game's art style is really cool.
- Their musics are very well composed, it is addicting and harmonic.  
- A sequel is set to be released in 2025.

For cons:
- It's addicting.

A disappointment for an overwhelmingly positive review.
(A review from a fan of roguelikes and deckbuilders)

- All based on RNG: RNG enemies, RNG loot, RNG map, and RNG combat. No direct achievement—you’re 100% dependent on good RNG to progress through the first map, less so on the second, and by the third, if you make it, not at all. But this means you’ll be "rolling the dice" every time just to be able to play.

- Too linear: Not much to offer. Because of all the RNG, you get a random game each time, but this doesn’t change the fact that you’ll be doing the same thing over and over again.

- No good objectives: I know this is a roguelike, not a roguelite, but besides unlocking more content, there’s no real reason to grind out a good game every single time.

In the end, I understand that this is a 7-year-old game, and when it was released, it was probably groundbreaking. But today, any game with these elements will deliver a better experience. If you want to try it, go for it, but keep in mind that it’s not worth the full price.

Good game, but I managed to beat it on my 8th run. Runs into a problem where the more you unlock the more difficult it is to do your build.

To make this game significantly better, I'd suggest creating some kind of a PvP mode where the final battle involves you versing others who made it to the end of the climb. I'd also suggest scrapping the idea that each character has a unique set of cards as this makes the idea of creating multiple characters too big of a task and instead focus on having 50 different characters with the only thing distinguishing them is aesthetics and beginning passive. The problem with making each character so specifically diverse and unique is that it accidentally creates a supremacy system where there's no point in picking certain characters.

I also felt as though the upgrades for the characters being cards wasn't what I wanted. I would have preferred if the upgrades were passive buffs rather than extra activation cards. On my 5th run I came to the realisation that "Power Cards" combined with "Relics" were truly the only things that mattered in the game. Attack cards and Skill cards were nowhere near as powerful as passive bonuses. The cards being tucked in at the bottom of the screen the way they were was a bit annoying to read as you had to move your mouse left and right just to see what each card did rather than being able to comprehend all of them at once and come to a strategic conclusion without forgetting what was in your hand.

enough has been said about StS, yes it's that good. It's honestly very rare for a game to inspire an entire genre and remain the best game in that genre for half a decade and counting. The magical thing about StS is it's a rare kind of video game you can revisit after a few years and, nothing in it has changed, but somehow, it feels completely different. You see the game with new eyes and suddenly all of your previous assumptions are a jumbled mess again. Your old reliable strategies suddenly stopped working, what changed? Cards you never looked twice at are suddenly crushing a run for you. A character you never fully understood clicks. A character you thought you'd mastered is completely eluding you.

Slay the Spire is a really good roguelike deckbuilder. But the thing it has that many of its would-be successors do not is mystique. Can this or that thing be made to work? Is it good? How do you know when you can take it? Was that a fluke, or did you just invent a playstyle you hadn't considered until its pieces materialized for you? You won a run, impressive. Can you do it again, but cleaner this time, without coming so close to dying at this or that point--that deck was fun, could you have built it better, what was its core, what did you think was necessary but wasn't?

Everything answer you arrive to in Slay the Spire is met with more questions. The game doesn't ask you them, it just presents problems and pieces of solutions. It teaches you to be curious, open-minded, and creative, beckons you to try and then try again. It isn't just special for the obvious reasons that it is well-designed, balanced, a fun interplay of little challenges and exciting rewards. It is special because it infects you with a mental itch that nothing else really seems to scratch. You begin by trying to overcome a run, and end up trying to overcome an ocean.

How incredibly appropriate that at the beginning of the game, we are greeted by a monstrous whale.
This is an amazing deck building game that keeps you fully engaged and want to do different runs to try new strategies and progress with different heros.

Slay the spire has been an absolute break-out title that revolutionized and frankly rocketed the genre into the stratosphere. It's difficult to find any deck-building rogue-like that doesn't take direct influence from this game, and the reasons are in spades. 
The game is extremely easy to pick up and play, and through playing you'll unlock a couple handfuls of extra cards for each character. These unlocks help put into your mind various builds you can find or curate for a character on a given run. It takes extreme consideration and skill to develop a catalog of cards that can be generally good when put into a random deck, but then really shine when paired with others like it.
Everything about this game is fantastic and I heartily recommend playing it.

I think this is the first game I've played where I genuinely have no idea what people see in it. After playing Balatro, I was looking for another card game and this is popular on here and recommended on reddit. Maybe this is something you can play on your phone? And it is really good compared to other phone games? When learning the mechanics I found a streamer that had played the game for 5000 hours. I can only imagine the kind of trauma he was dealing with at the time to use this crappy, shallow game as a diversion.

Overall, I found the game to be tedious and unrewarding. Though that is really underselling it: I would audibly groan when faced with a mob of enemies because it meant a turn might last longer. The worst part of the game was actually playing a round, and everything else (shops, route selection) was just a nice break from the tedium of the core gameplay. I have three main complaints:

1) It is visually static. Numbers sometimes appear on-screen and there is a slashing animation, but nothing seems to actually happen. It is like watching a freeze-frame highlight reel, and an uneventful one at that. I kept waiting for there to be something on-screen that seemed to justify the time I was spending. But there is nothing. At the end your character is on the ground (there isn't even a proper death animation) and you get a summary list of some stats. That's it? Really? And when you win it isn't much better. I really struggle to see how people are feeling rewarded by a game that gives you nothing back.

2) The decision-making process behind card selection is extremely obvious. There is no fun to be had thinking of how cards might combine in interesting ways, because 99% of the time they either don't combine or you get maybe 1 card in your hand that combines with another. But even then, it isn't challenging - everything is so obvious that you feel like the game may as well be playing itself.

3) The game really suffers from the RNG deck-building mechanics. Given the incredibly shallow mechanics, you can see how the game might actually be fun if you could make more choices initially to set things up in interesting ways. But what happens in practice is that you are given a very limited number of choices based on luck. It's not just that a run becomes better or worse due to luck, luck factors into whether the game is even halfway interesting to play. And most of the time it just isn't.

After about 200 hours (which is—considering how deep this game is—not a lot at all) and after getting every single achievement, both on Steam and in the in-game percentage counter, I can confidently say that Slay the Spire—made by Mega Crit—is my favorite Roguelike Deckbuilder (and a Card Game in general), surpassing everything I've experienced in a similar genre, whether single-player or multiplayer.

There are four playable characters in Slay the Spire, each with its own unique flavor, design, cards, mechanics, relics, and builds. This variety offers countless ways to play, allowing you to navigate through challenging encounters, pick and remove cards along the way, improve your deck, and face challenging (but not unfair) bosses in each act. While the game is not difficult to grasp in its fundamentals—especially if you've played other card games and deckbuilders—it is quite challenging and mechanically deep. But worry not; each loss is a learning experience that enhances your knowledge and skills, eventually bringing you to a point where you can comfortably and consistently beat the game on 0/low Ascensions—the term that refers to an additional difficulty system that is unlocked after the player has successfully completed a run with a character. Each Ascension level, naturally, increases the game's difficulty by adding new challenges, such as tougher enemies, reduced rewards, and more. High Ascensions are, of course, extremely challenging but all the more satisfying when you beat them. This, coupled with how many different ways a run can go, offers near-infinite replay value.

As far as the art style is concerned, you'll hear mixed opinions. This was a surprise for me at first because I have nothing against it and actually like it very much. It is simple, yes, but quite unique in its own way—pleasant to look at. However, the UI/Menu sections of the game could use some work—they are completely functional, but I think aesthetically they had a lot more potential. In addition to this, the fact that there are no unlockable skins for the characters, no unlockable card frames, and no additional card arts (apart from Beta arts, but that's it) is quite unfortunate, as these features would help keep certain aesthetic aspects of the game feel fresh and diverse. I hope they add these features in Slay the Spire 2. And polish the game a bit more, as it still has few bugs and glitches here and there, some allowing you to exploit game mechanics. 

Sound effects—like the clicking sounds, the sounds of flipping a page, etc.—are extremely satisfying and competently done, but the soundtrack, in my opinion, is a mixed bag. It’s not bad by any means, but it can get quite boring and repetitive.

Overall, Slay the Spire is a masterful blend of strategy, challenge, and replayability, making it a standout in the Roguelike Deckbuilder genre. Despite few minor shortcomings and specific avenues that can be improved, the game offers a deeply rewarding experience that keeps you coming back for more. Whether you’re a seasoned card game enthusiast or a newcomer, this game is definitely worth your time.

A series of Final Fantasy style battles where you attack in turn based on cards in your hand. Cards are received and upgraded after each battle.

* Pleasantly easy to get into. No information overload when you start
* UI makes it easy to play strategically (e.g. a +6 attack card will show +4 when debuffed so you don't have to remember)
* Card effects are simple to predict, making it easy to plan ahead and get synergy
* Extreme replay value (like Hades, FTL, etc)

My only complaints are that card effects can't be read without hovering each one, and music doesn't immediately stop when pressing Escape (alt-tab works though).
